awd_titl_txt: Revealing the state space of turbulent wall-bounded shear flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Cvitanovic
DMS-1211827

     A large conceptual gap separates the theory of low-dimensional chaotic dynamics from the infinite-dimensional nonlinear dynamics of turbulence.  Advances in experimental imaging, computational methods, and dynamical systems theory suggest a way to bridge this gap and make a fundamental breakthrough in our understanding of turbulence.  It has recently been discovered that recurrent coherent structures observed in wall-bounded shear flows (such as pipes and boundary layers) result from close passes to weakly unstable invariant solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations.  These 3D, fully nonlinear solutions (equilibria, traveling waves, and periodic orbits) structure the state space of turbulent flows and provide a skeleton for analyzing their dynamics.  The investigator calculates a hierarchy of invariant solutions for a canonical wall-bounded shear flow and uses these solutions to develop a geometrical and quantitative description of the flow's turbulent dynamics.  He uses a combination of novel and proven numerical and analytical techniques, such as periodic orbit theory, group representation theory, nonlinear search methods, variational solvers, and computational fluid dynamics.  The project is conducted with collaborators in Japan, Germany, the UK, and the US, and all results and numerical software are disseminated through the investigator's collaborative e-book www.ChaosBook.org. 

     Turbulence is not only the great unsolved fundamental problem of classical physics, but a problem of great practical importance for technology and engineering, where turbulence is exhibited by cardiac systems, electromagnetic plasmas, oceans, and the atmosphere.  A mathematical description of turbulent phenomena is of necessity high-dimensional, and accurate prediction requires solving millions of equations.  Modern advances in computation and experimental data analysis have brought such computations within reach.  Even more recent is the discovery of "recurrent coherent structures," whorls that one observes over and over in structures such as clouds.  Such structures enable us to classify types of turbulent states in a mathematically precise manner and to predict their evolution without resorting to further large-scale computations.  The project aims to deploy these "coherent structures" as a platform from which to chart the extremely high-dimensional world of all possible turbulent states, create an atlas over the important ones, and give a detailed predictive (as opposed to statistical) description of turbulent motions.  Any progress in fundamental understanding of turbulence affects applications that range from the suppression of plasma instabilities in magnetic confinement fusion reactors, to weather prediction, to the key challenge of reducing turbulent drag.  Even an incremental reduction of, for instance, turbulent drag by insights so achieved might have a significant economic impact, because drag is responsible for a significant part of the fuel consumed in transportation.

Intellectual Merit:

Transition to turbulence in fluids remains one of the unsolved problems of physics, despite its importance to various fields of science and engineering, ranging from aerodynamics to astrophysics. Traditionally turbulence is viewed as a 3D flow, Fig. 1, and treated as a statistical phenomenon, with statistics of physical observables extracted from laboratory and computer experiments. In the modern, dynamical approach, turbulence is viewed as a motion in the infinite dimensional function space (state space) of solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations. This point of view complements the traditional 3D spatio-temporal visualizations of turbulent flows by providing dynamical insights in the organization of a given turbulent flow. Dynamics in this state space is shaped by the `exact coherent solutions’. Our novel visualization techniques use these solutions to construct intrinsic coordinates, on which projections of turbulent solutions reveal dynamical organization of the turbulent flow, see Fig. 2.

 

The research performed under this grant has focused on one experimentally important flow geometry, the pipe flow. Taking account of symmetries turned out to be a greater challenge than we had anticipated. A novel symmetry reduction scheme for systems (pipes, channel flows) symmetric under translations, rotations and reflections that we have formulated has (1) enabled us to, for the first time, determine a hierarchy of a large number of unstable relative periodic orbits in a transitionally turbulent pipe flow, and (2) provided strong evidence that these invariant solutions form the backbone of the turbulent flow (as illustrated by their embedding into the ergodic sea, see Fig. 3).

 

Another fundamental question about the nature of turbulence in viscous flows is: what is the dimension of the turbulent attractor? A recent conjecture is that this dimension can be determined by study of leading stability eigenvectors (covariant Lyapunov vectors). The computational challenge here is that for even the shortest periodic solutions, the matrix elements of the linearized flow Jacobian can range over some 10^(-3,000) orders of magnitude (!). Our `Schur’ algorithm is --for our research goals-- a major technical breakthrough in this direction. Tested on a one-dimensional turbulent flame front, it enables us to compute a large number of stability eigenvectors, and determine the dimension of a turbulent attractor.

We are now poised to raise the theory to the next level: develop methods to describe turbulence in large spatial domains and determine the dimensions of their attractors. Both numerical and foundational challenges ahead are daunting: porting the Schur method to 3D Navier-Stokes flows remains a major challenge for future research, and so far the exact solutions for larger computational domains have been difficult to determine. New ideas that combine our work on small computational domains with the theory of pattern formation on large domains will be needed to surmount these challenges.




Broader Impact:
In the long run this research promises to yield quantitative, predictive description of moderate Reynolds number turbulence, and tools to exploit this description to control flows and explain their statistics. It is a radically new approach to thinking about fluids, and has already begun to have a broader impact, motivating new experiments and new approaches to other engineering, medical and biophysical problems exhibiting turbulence, such as cardiac dynamics (pursued with experimentalists and theorists in the parallel NSF CDI #1028133). The collaboration has put much effort into outreach, in order to bring these recent exciting developments to researchers in earth and atmospheric sciences, engineering, mathematics, astrophysics and neurosciences.
